item.title: Événement annuel sur la cybersécurité : Pensez cybersécurité (Salle de discussion 2)
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
Salle de discussion 2
Dans cette séance, vous examinerez comment l’intelligence artificielle (IA) transforme le numérique, et comment son recoupement avec la cybersécurité donne à la fois lieu à des possibilités de transformation et à des problèmes urgents. La présentation mettra l’accent sur l’évolution des répercussions de l’IA sur la cybersécurité et sur la façon dont les gouvernements, les industries et les institutions peuvent maximiser les avantages de l’adoption de l’IA, tout en gérant de façon proactive les risques qu’elle entraîne.
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=DDN2-E37&cm_locale=fr

item.title: Annual Cyber Security Event: Get Cyber Safe—for Future You (Breakout 2)
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
Breakout 2
In this session, you will examine how artificial intelligence (AI) is reshaping the digital landscape, with its intersection with cyber security bringing both transformative opportunities and pressing challenges. The presentation will highlight the evolving impact of AI on cyber security and focus on how governments, industries, and institutions can maximize the benefits of AI adoption while proactively managing emerging risks
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=DDN2-E37&cm_locale=en

item.title: Événement annuel sur la cybersécurité : Pensez cybersécurité (Salle de discussion 1)
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
Salle de discussion 1
Dans cette séance, vous explorerez comment la sécurité nationale est touchée par l’utilisation croissante des appareils intelligents. Vous découvrirez comment les auteurs et auteures de cybermenaces peuvent utiliser ces appareils pour accéder à de l’information et causer du tort. La discussion portera sur des moyens simples de repérer les risques liés à la cybersécurité et de vous protéger, vous ainsi que votre organisation.
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=DDN2-E37&cm_locale=fr

item.title: Annual Cyber Security Event: Get Cyber Safe—for Future You (Breakout 1)
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
Breakout 1
In this session, you will explore how national security is affected by the growing use of smart devices. You will gain insight into how cyber-threat actors can use these devices to access information and cause harm. The discussion will focus on simple ways to spot cyber-risks and protect yourself and your organization.
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=DDN2-E37&cm_locale=en

item.title: Événement annuel sur la cybersécurité : Pensez cybersécurité – aujourd’hui pour demain (Plénière)
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
Cet événement opportun porte sur les conséquences croissantes des cybermenaces à l’échelle nationale, sur le rôle de l’intelligence artificielle et sur l’importance de reconnaître la mésinformation et la désinformation en vue de prévenir les cyberattaques et d’y résister.
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=DDN2-E37&cm_locale=fr

item.title: Annual Cyber Security Event: Get Cyber Safe—for Future You (Plenary)
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
This timely event explores the increasing national impact of cyber threats, including the role artificial intelligence plays and the importance of recognizing misinformation and disinformation to prevent and resist cyber attacks. It highlights emerging tactics used by threat actors, such as deepfakes, and emphasize the critical need for public servants to remain vigilant in safeguarding digital systems, data, and information.
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=DDN2-E37&cm_locale=en

item.title: Améliorer l'intendance environnementale et les politiques grâce à la science autochtone
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
Cet enregistrement d'événement porte sur la manière dont la science autochtone permet d'améliorer l'intendance environnementale et d'éclairer les politiques publiques, alors qu'on présente le fruit du travail de Myrle Ballard visant à faire le pont entre les systèmes de savoirs autochtones et occidentaux à l'échelle gouvernementale, universitaire et communautaire.
https://www.csps-efpc.gc.ca/video/indigenous-science-fra.aspx

item.title: Enhancing Environmental Stewardship and Policy Development Through Indigenous Science
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
This event recording explores how Indigenous science enhances environmental stewardship and informs public policy, highlighting Dr. Myrle Ballard's work in bridging Indigenous and Western knowledge systems across government, academia, and community.
https://www.csps-efpc.gc.ca/video/indigenous-science-eng.aspx

item.title: Série Café virtuel de l’EFPC : Discussion sur la santé mentale, avec Bill Howatt
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
Cet enregistrement d'événement met en vedette Bill Howatt, Ph. D., expert en santé mentale au travail reconnu mondialement, qui traite de l’importance des connaissances en santé mentale, du but du milieu de travail et du leadership axé sur l’intelligence émotionnelle dans la fonction publique fédérale d’aujourd’hui.
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=WMT2-E21&cm_locale=fr

item.title: CSPS Virtual Café Series: A Conversation on Mental Health with Dr. Bill Howatt
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
This event recording features Dr. Bill Howatt, an international expert in workplace mental health, who elaborates on the importance of mental health literacy, workplace purpose and emotionally intelligent leadership in today's federal public service.
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=WMT2-E21&cm_locale=en

item.title: Trouver la motivation grâce à l’inspiration et au bien-être
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
Cet enregistrement d'événement porte sur les principes fondamentaux de la motivation dans un contexte professionnel, ainsi que sur les stratégies pratiques que les chefs d’organisation peuvent utiliser pour inspirer leur équipe, reconnaître concrètement les contributions et promouvoir la sécurité psychologique.
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=TRN4-E47&cm_locale=fr

item.title: Finding Motivation Through Inspiration and Well-Being
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
This event recording examines the core principles of employee motivation, plus practical strategies that leaders can use to inspire their teams, recognize contributions meaningfully, and promote psychological safety.
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=TRN4-E47&cm_locale=en

item.title: Série sur l’exploration de l’énergie au Canada : Faire le point sur la sécurité énergétique
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
Cet enregistrement d'événement instructif permet d’examiner la capacité du Canada à offrir de l’énergie fiable et abordable en passant en revue des points historiques marquants et en mettant en lumière la réalité de la précarité énergétique qui touche plusieurs membres de la population canadienne.
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=FON1-E48&cm_locale=fr

item.title: Exploring Energy in Canada Series: Unpacking Energy Security
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
This informative event recording explores Canada’s ability to ensure reliable, affordable energy by reviewing key historical events and illuminating the reality of energy poverty still faced by many Canadians.
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=FON1-E48&cm_locale=en

item.title: Rodd Charlottetown - Charlottetown, PEI
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
The Rodd family has been a driving force in Atlantic Canada’s tourism industry for 90 years, and their stunning renovation of Rodd Charlottetown this year shows they have no plans of slowing down.
Transcript The Rodd Charlottetown Hotel has been welcoming guests since 1931. The oldest heritage hotel in Prince Edward Island, the property combines old world charm with modern amenities. With 115 rooms, a restaurant and Victorian-style conference rooms, the full-service hotel is a cornerstone of the downtown core. It's one of four remaining hotels built across the country by Canadian National Railway. In 2024, the historic property began an extensive $10 million renovation. The major project included restoration of the building’s brick exterior, upgrades to the guest rooms and improvements to energy efficiency. The goal is to preserve the historical integrity of the building while preparing the property for another 100 years. ACOA is proud to support the Rodd Charlottetown Hotel as they honour the past and seize today’s opportunities.

item.title: Série L’impact des données : Perspectives internationales sur la maturité en matière de données
item.author: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.source: Canada School of PS / École de la FP du Canada
item.content:encoded:
Organisé par la Communauté des données du GC, cet enregistrement d'événement porte sur la manière dont les fonctions publiques du Royaume-Uni et de l’Australie évaluent la maturité en matière de données parmi leurs organisations, et met en lumière des leçons et des approches pertinentes dans le contexte canadien.
https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=DDN3-E54&cm_locale=fr

item.title: The Smart Energy Company - Upper Golden Grove, New Brunswick
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded: The Smart Energy Company is helping farmers cut costs & embrace sustainability. With ACOA’s support, this Atlantic Canadian small biz is scaling clean energy across Canada.

item.title: Emmerson Packaging – Amherst, Nova Scotia
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Emmerson Packaging is a 3rd-generation family-owned manufacturer and supplier of premium flexible packaging. The company is investing to reduce its carbon footprint and save money, estimating that modern equipment purchased with ACOA support will save $500,000 a year.
Trancript Emmerson Packaging estimates modern equipment purchased with ACOA support will save $500,000 a year.
The 3rd-generation family business has 450 employees and 2 facilities in Amherst, Nova Scotia and Belleville, Ontario.
It manufactures and supplies premium flexible packaging to industries across North America.
As a certified Sustainable Green Printer, Emmerson Packaging makes sustainability a priority.
Its new laminator will decrease energy use by 20%, decrease waste, and create 12 new jobs.
The company is investing to reduce its carbon footprint and save money.

item.title: From Fences to Firewalls: Cyber security in agriculture
item.author: Agriculture and Agri-food Canada
item.content:encoded: From phones and computers to automated systems in barns and data collection in harvesters, each piece of technology on a farm is a fantastic tool – and a potential weak point. And hackers look for – weak points. Just as producers protect livestock and crops from predators, they need to do the same to protect their technology. In this episode, Dr. Ali Dehghantanha, Canada Research Chair in cyber security at the University of Guelph, explains how producers can stay a few simple and innovative steps ahead of the criminals. And Charles-Félix Ross, Director General of Quebec’s UPA, shares what happened when his organization was hit by ransomware and the key lessons learned. Learn more about the Toolkit.

item.title: Psychological Health and Safety in Action with Troy Winters
item.content:encoded: When thinking about workplace health and safety, physical safety is usually top of mind. But for a workplace to be truly healthy and safe, psychological safety is also an essential component. Troy Winters, National Health and Safety Coordinator for CUPE, joins us to discuss what that looks like in practice.

item.title: The Defence Advantage: Built in Atlantic Canada
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic Canada is driving Canada’s defence industry — with innovation, talent, and technology that keep our country secure. From shipbuilding to maintenance and repairs, simulation and training, ground vehicle solutions, cyber resilience, and advanced manufacturing, this region is shaping the future of defence and security. See how Atlantic Canada is: • Building world-class solutions in the land, naval and aerospace domains • Creating highly skilled jobs and long-term growth • Strengthening Canada’s security at home and abroad #AtlanticCanada #DefenceIndustry #Innovation #AerospaceandDefence #Security #shipbuildingstocks
Transcription: Canada’s defence future is being built right here in Atlantic Canada. At COVE, where companies fast-track, test, and validate new technology. At NATO’s Defence Innovation Accelerator for the North Atlantic - known as DIANA – where innovators access funding, mentorship, and NATO’s global innovation network. At PAL Aerospace and IMP Aerospace & Defence - where skilled workers keep our skies secure, coasts monitored, and military aircraft ready-to-fly. At Irving Shipbuilding – where Canada’s next-generation naval and coast guard vessels are being built. And at Atlantic Canada Aerospace & Defence Association member companies across the region, serving both commercial and defence markets globally. Atlantic Canada goes above and beyond to support national defence efforts. And with more defence spending coming, this region is ready to lead. Atlantic Canada’s defence industry is a national strength. We have the people and the know-how to lead the way, and build a safer world.

item.title: Story of our logo
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
These trees have stood tall for centuries.
The Lodgepole Pine and Mount Kidd are more than just Canadian natural landmarks – they represent the #G7’s resilience and hold special significance to local Treaty 7 Nations.
#G7Canada #G7Kananaskis2025 #Treaty7

item.title: Bridgewater Ready Mix, Bridgewater, Nova Scotia
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Bridgewater Ready Mix in NS is making concrete more eco-friendly. With support from ACOA, it’s producing greener concrete and cutting emissions. The company plans to switch to clean energy and reduce CO₂ by 40% by 2030.
Transcript Bridgewater Ready Mix in Bridgewater, Nova Scotia takes concrete performance and global warming seriously. The company is committed to the industry’s plan for net-zero concrete by 2050. With help from ACOA, Bridgewater Ready Mix is increasing green concrete production. Its greening initiatives include many factors. The company is the first in the province to publish Type III Environmental Product Declarations. This provides transparent, objective, and third-party verified data about the environmental performance of its products. The company is an early adopter of limestone cement, which reduces emissions by up to 10% compared to regular cement. And it is making plans to switch to cleaner energy resources to power the plant, mix and transport cement. Greener products, with performance customers count on. Bridgewater Ready Mix aims to reach a 40% CO2 reduction by 2030 on the path to net-zero.

item.title: S5 Ep. 05 - Learning from One Another: Skills, Training, and Workforce Development in Northern Communities
item.content:encoded: In this episode of the Future Skills Podcast, host Jeremy Strachan explores the complex and evolving landscape of skills development and workforce training in Northern and Indigenous communities. Amanda Thompson from The Conference Board of Canada shares insights from the Learning from One Another project, a multi-year initiative examining labour market trends and training strategies across Yukon, Nunavut, and Northern Ontario. We also hear from Kris Mullaly of the Qikiqtani Inuit Association, who discusses the Q-STEP program and Tuttarvik—community-driven initiatives that are empowering Inuit youth through culturally grounded training and employment supports. Finally, Xina Cowan of EntrepreNorth highlights how entrepreneurship is creating new pathways for economic resilience and self-determination across the North.Amanda Thompson, Lead Research Associate, The Conference Board of CanadaKris Mullaly, Program Manager, Qikiqtani Inuit AssociationXina Cowan, Co-Director, Skills Council of Canada

item.title: Canada’s Impact in Papua New Guinea
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded: As Canada and Papua New Guinea celebrate 50 years of diplomatic relations, we’re looking back to a proud moment of partnership. See how one Canadian physiotherapist sparked lasting change in Papua New Guinea’s physiotherapy landscape 35 years ago.

item.title: Prévenir les maladies respiratoires infectieuses au travail
item.content:encoded: Les maladies respiratoires infectieuses peuvent se propager facilement en milieu de travail, et leurs symptômes varient de légers à très graves. Nous discutons des mesures que nous pouvons tous prendre pour nous protéger et protéger les autres pendant la saison du rhume et de la grippe.

item.title: Preventing Respiratory Infectious Diseases in the Workplace
item.content:encoded: Respiratory infectious diseases can spread easily in the workplace, with symptoms ranging from mild to very serious. We discuss the steps we can all take to protect ourselves and others during cold and flu season.

item.title: Global Affairs Canada: We are Canada in the world. 🇨🇦🤝🌎
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
Global Affairs Canada works every day to shape a more peaceful, prosperous, and sustainable world for Canadians
We deliver by: 🆘 Providing trusted support to Canadians abroad 📈 Opening doors for Canadian businesses 🕊️ Promoting peace, democracy, and human rights 🌱 Driving climate action and inclusive development
Because what happens globally shapes life here at home.
We are Canada in the world. 🇨🇦🤝🌎

item.title: Ability NB and the Municipality of Grand Lake - New Brunswick
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Accessibility is more than a checklist — it’s a mindset.
Thanks to a partnership between Ability New Brunswick and the Municipality of Grand Lake, supported by ACOA, rural communities are embracing inclusive design and transforming public spaces.
This story shows how thoughtful collaboration can lead to lasting impact — and a more accessible future for everyone.
Executive Director of Ability NB, Haley Flaro, says: “This is our first collaboration with ACOA, and it’s a shining example of what’s possible when federal partners work hand-in-hand with communities.”
Transcript: Alyson:
It all started we were planning to make some renovations to the washroom facilities at the Chipman Heritage Centre.
We knew kinda through residents that they were not easily accessible in a wheelchair or mobility aid.
I ended up speaking with Ability New Brunswick. They let us know that they actually had a free accessibility review that they could do of our buildings.
We learned so much about tactical signage, making sure that our spaces are cane friendly.
It was so much more than just ensuring that people can enter the building.
And from there, we've really started a wonderful collaboration with them that we know will continue past just these buildings.
We have more throughout the municipality, and we are also just really doing our best to promote it to other private businesses in the community.
Haley Flaro:
I just love this collaboration because it’s a perfect example of community working with community.
And the large tourism that happens, especially in the Grand Lake area drawing more people in to the communities to be able to access important museums, infrastructure, you know, recreation areas.
It’s really critical., so we’re really proud of this collaboration.

item.title: Global Affairs Canada: We are Canada in the world. 🇨🇦🤝🌎
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded: Global Affairs Canada works every day to shape a more peaceful, prosperous, and sustainable world for Canadians. 🍁

item.title: G7s In Canada
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
Canada hosted the #G7 Summit for the 7th time this year. From Montebello in 1981 to Charlevoix in 2018, Canada has welcomed world leaders as they worked to take action on global issues.
Watch this video to learn about key moments from our six previous G7 presidencies!
#G7Kananaskis #G7Canada

item.title: PEI Preserve Co. - New Glasgow, Prince Edward Island
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
The PEI Preserve Company is celebrating 40 years of good taste and tradition 🎉🍓🫐 A pioneer in the Canadian specialty food industry, the company is embracing innovation and automation so they can spread preserves and joy around the world!
Transcript - Built on old-fashioned values of quality and hospitality, the PEI Preserve Co. has been a pioneer in the Canadian specialty food industry since 1985. Founded by Bruce and Shirley MacNaughton, a humble jar of handmade preserves quickly transformed into an iconic Island business. The operation blossomed to include a river-front restaurant, gift shop, theatre café, 12 acres of gardens, a butterfly house... ...and of course... ...preserves! The preserves are sold worldwide through the company’s online giftshop, and in three locations across the Island. In 2022, the company was purchased by Adam and Marsha Doiron, who held strong ties to the business and saw its growth potential. The Doirons celebrated the company’s 40th “Jam-iversary” in 2025, welcoming all who have been a part of the PEI Preserve Co. story. It was a joyful afternoon full of flavour, music and reflection. And special guest Chef Michael Smith opened the 5-millionth jar! PEI Preserve Co. produces up to 100,000 jars per year, and demand continues to grow. So, what’s next? The Doirons have plans to expand the product line and scale up production to 500,000 jars per year by 2027. The Government of Canada is helping businesses like PEI Preserve Co. become more productive and reach new markets. ACOA is proud to support PEI Preserve Co. as they spread jam and joy around the world!

item.title: Treasury Board at a glance
item.author: TBS Canada
item.content:encoded:
This video is also available in French: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fKK5FauNZek Video produced by: TBS Communications
Transcript: The Treasury Board is a Cabinet committee chaired by the President of the Treasury Board and composed of a Vice-Chair, four or more standing members, and alternate members. Ministers play a corporate role and do not represent their individual portfolios when they take part in meetings. The Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat supports the Board administratively. It provides advice and recommendations. The Treasury Board has two distinct functions known as Part A and Part B. For Part A Ministers will consider proposals—Treasury Board submissions—from sponsoring ministers. These submissions seek access to funding and/or authorities, such as the ability to enter into contracts or undertake projects, to advance the government’s agenda. Treasury Board also approves the ruleset governing financial and project management, contracting, and people and IT management in the government. As the employer, Treasury Board will also be asked to approve collective agreements for the federal public service. Treasury Board considers about 350 proposals per year. For Part B: The Treasury Board also serves as the Governor in Council. It considers regulations and orders-in-council that are meant to protect the health, safety, or security of Canadians and the environment, and support a competitive and innovative economy. Annually, the Treasury Board considers 100 to 200 regulatory proposals. It also considers 200 to 300 non-regulatory orders-in-council including those that authorize Canada to enter into international agreements, or bring legislation into force. Regulations and orders-in-council are typically made public after approval. The Treasury Board usually meets once a week when Parliament is sitting, or more frequently when there are many submissions to consider. Each meeting includes a Part A and a Part B agenda and typically lasts two to three hours. Each Treasury Board submission, along with the Treasury Board Secretariat’s analysis and recommendation, is typically provided to ministers one week in advance of a Treasury Board meeting. A certain number of items are identified, or “flagged” in advance, because of their scope or profile, and are formally presented to Ministers at the meeting by senior officials from the Secretariat The other items are proposed for approval without discussion; however, during the meeting ministers can ask questions on any item on the agenda. Decisions from Treasury Board are then communicated to departments so they can start implementation or address the Board’s concerns.

item.title: Be Storm Ready When You Travel
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded: 🌴☀️ Travelling to a sunny destination? Tropical storms can happen—be prepared. Check our advice to be informed before you go abroad during #HurricaneSeason: https://travel.gc.ca/travelling/health-safety/hurricanes-typhoons-cyclones-monsoons

item.title: A Safe and Welcoming Workplace for Newcomers
item.content:encoded: Immigrants contribute significantly to Canada's economy but often face challenges that could impact their health and safety. We speak with Bill Chen of Workplace Safety and Protection Services on how workplaces can create safer and more welcoming environments for newcomers.

item.title: Regional Connectivity Envelope – Information Session EN
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded: This is a recording of the information session on the Regional Connectivity Envelope hosted by Global Affairs Canada.

item.title: Global Affairs Canada’s 2025 State of Trade report
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
Global Affairs Canada’s 2025 State of Trade report is out.
It shows that Canada’s trade hit new milestones despite global uncertainty.
In 2024, Canadian exports grew by 1.9%, reaching $997 billion.
Flow of Foreign direct investment (FDI) into Canada surged by 36.2% to $85.5 billion—the second-highest level in history.
The report is clear: Canada remains a top destination for global business.
Canada’s trade: reliable, bold, and global.
Read the full report: https://international.canada.ca/en/global-affairs/corporate/transparency/reports-publications/chief-economist/state-trade/2025

item.title: S5 Ep. 04 - Pathways to Self-Employment for Neurodivergent Canadians
item.content:encoded: In this episode of the Future Skills Podcast, host Jeremy Strachan explores how self-employment and entrepreneurship can serve as powerful pathways for neurodivergent Canadians to thrive in the workforce. Jennifer Fane from The Conference Board of Canada discusses her Future Skills Centre-funded research on barriers facing neurodivergent entrepreneurs and the need for tailored support programs; Wanda Deschamps, founder of Liberty Co. and openly autistic entrepreneur, shares her perspective on shifting the narrative from accommodations to strengths and the importance of neuroinclusion in business; and Brad Loiselle, CEO of Skills Council of Canada, reveals how “dyslexic thinking” has fueled his serial entrepreneurship success, from building North America’s largest wrapping paper business to creating innovative educational platforms. Jennifer Fane, Lead Research Associate, The Conference Board of CanadaWanda Deschamps, Founder and Principal, Liberty Co.Brad Loiselle, CEO and Founder, Skills Council of Canada

item.title: Canadians Just Aren't California Dreamin' These Days
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: Calllllll-i-forrrrr-nia... here we come? If you've changed your plans to visit the US recently, you're not alone. Nowadays, Canadians are more likely to be singing along to "Bobcaygeon" than "Sweet Home Alabama."Today, we're sitting down with Jane Lin, of the Tourism Statistics Program at Statistics Canada, to dig into StatCan's tourism data and talk about how travel is different these days.

item.title: G7 Leaders' Summit 2025: Closing Remarks
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
Closing remarks of the G7 Leaders’ Summit delivered by the Right Honourable Mark Carney, Prime Minister of Canada, on June 17, 2025.
Canada hosted G7 leaders and partners for two days of open talks that led to agreements on priorities such as critical minerals, quantum tech, AI adoption, wildfires, and transnational crime.
#G7Kananaskis2025 #G7Canada

item.title: G7 Leaders' Summit 2025: Opening Remarks
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
Opening remarks of the G7 Leaders’ Summit delivered by the Right Honourable Mark Carney, Prime Minister of Canada, on June 16, 2025.
The eyes of the world were upon the #G7 Summit as partner nations tackled issues such as international peace and security, economic prosperity, critical minerals, energy security, artificial intelligence and more.
#g7kananaskis2025 #g7canada

item.title: Opening new markets in the Indo-Pacific
item.author: Agriculture and Agri-food Canada
item.content:encoded: How do we open new markets in diverse and dynamic countries? What challenges do we face, and what solutions are being used? Chris White, President and CEO of the Canadian Meat Council, and Diedrah Kelly, Executive Director of the Indo-Pacific Agriculture and Agri-Food Office in Manila, share their insights. From building strong trade relationships to promoting Canada’s trusted brand, this episode explores the work needed to grow Canada’s presence in one of the world’s fastest-growing regions.

item.title: S5 Ep. 03: AI in the Workplace and the Skills that Matter Most
item.content:encoded: In this episode of the Future Skills Podcast, host Jeremy Strachan explores the transformative world of Artificial Intelligence and its impact on the Canadian workforce. With insights from experts Noel Baldwin, Stephanie Enders, and Mark Patterson, we hear how Future Skills Centre research is helping us better understand the way AI is reshaping job markets, skills development, and employment strategies. The conversation tackles critical challenges like AI literacy, ethical considerations, and the need for adaptability in a rapidly evolving technological landscape. Discover how workers and businesses can leverage AI to enhance human skills, improve productivity, and navigate the future of work.Noel Baldwin, Executive Director, Future Skills CentreStephanie Enders, Chief Delivery Officer, Alberta Machine Intelligence Institute (Amii)Mark Patterson, Executive Director, Magnet

item.title: A Tariff on Both Your Houses
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: Two countries, both alike in dignity, In North America, where we lay our scene, From ancient friendship break to new trade tragedy, Of data on trade and tariffs, what might we glean? Join us as we speak with Guy Gellatly, Chief Economic Advisor, at Statistics Canada, as we explore what’s been going on with trade with our closest neighbour, what the early numbers suggest about the conflict, and what impact it might have on Canada’s economy.

item.title: Creating Workplaces Where Everyone Can Thrive
item.content:encoded: Despite legislation designed to protect the rights of two-spirit, trans and non-binary people in Canada, many still face discrimination in their daily lives, including at work or seeking employment. A recent study by Egale Canada seeks to better understand their challenges.

item.title: One-year anniversary of the modernized Canada-Ukraine Free Trade Agreement
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
This year we mark the one-year anniversary of the modernized Canada-Ukraine Free Trade Agreement!
Despite Russia’s ongoing illegal and unjustified war of aggression, the Canada-Ukraine partnership continues
The modernized Canada-Ukraine Free Trade Agreement (CUFTA): ✅ supports long-term security, stability and economic recovery in #Ukraine ✅ ️provides improved market access for Canadian exporters ✅ provides a strong foundation for trade and investment
A win-win for everyone.
For more info: https://www.international.gc.ca/trade-commerce/trade-agreements-accords-commerciaux/agr-acc/ukraine/about-a_propos.aspx?lang=eng

item.title: Episode 9: It pays to grow up: Tax tips when starting to work or starting post-secondary studies
item.source: Taxology – The Official Canada Revenue Agency Podcast
item.content:encoded: Starting your first job or attending university or college? If so, congrats on the big life changes! This episode of Taxology will help you get ready. You may be wondering what your new situation means for your taxes. You may have to do them for the very first time. But don’t worry, we’re here for you! You’ll learn that not everyone has to pay at tax time. You could actually get more money back with a refund, and you could be eligible for benefits and credits. In this episode, we chat remotely with an expert who helps Canadians learn about their taxes and will share their knowledge with you!

item.title: Porter Talk #6: Porters and the Making of Modern Canada
item.author: Discover Library and Archives Canada
item.content:encoded: In the final episode of Porter Talk, we dive into how union gains paved the way for a brighter future for Black communities in Canada. This fight for basic human rights significantly contributed to a stronger and more progressive Canada for all. (Episode 6) Transcript

item.title: Registration of Canadians Abroad
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
Planning a trip outside Canada? Register with us for direct notifications about your destination, such as: 🚨, Picture important information in case of a natural disaster or civil unrest 🚨, Picture instructions to follow during an emergency 🚨, Picture travel advice updates that could affect your safety
You can register multiple destinations and co-travellers. Find out more: https://ow.ly/57S650RblZ6

item.title: Travelling with medication
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
One of our consular officers has some important information to share! If you are travelling outside of Canada with medication: -ensure it is legal in the country you are visiting -keep it in its original labelled container -bring a copy of the original prescription
For more useful information: https://ow.ly/CY8G50TPLKU

item.title: Support for Canadians Facing a Death Overseas
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded:
How can the government help if a loved one dies while outside of Canada? Listen to some important information from a consular official.
Officials can: - provide advice on how to get in touch with the appropriate authorities - authenticate the local death certificate for insurance or repatriation purposes
Officials can’t: - pay for the repatriation of remains - provide legal advice
For more information: https://ow.ly/3Vpj50UsCc0

item.title: Travel Checklist For Canadians Going Abroad
item.author: Global Affairs Canada
item.content:encoded: Whether you're dreaming of sandy beaches, bustling cities, or serene countryside, don’t forget to read up on your destination on travel.gc.ca and register with us before you go! https://ow.ly/Hazu50V66pF

item.title: Porter Talk: Episode 6 Trailer
item.author: Discover Library and Archives Canada
item.content:encoded: In the final episode of Porter Talk, we dive into how union gains paved the way for a brighter future for Black communities in Canada. This fight for basic human rights significantly contributed to a stronger and more progressive Canada for all. (Episode 6 trailer)TranscriptNarrator Biographies

item.title: Kings County Roadtrip, PEI
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
There’s never been a better time to hit the road and support Canadian businesses and communities. Hop in and buckle up as we take a trip through Kings County, Prince Edward Island! 🚗🗺️
Transcription Let’s take a trip through Kings County, PEI! This 2-day itinerary is jam packed with authentic sights, flavours and experiences. Follow along! Stop #1 Overnight at 45 Steps Inn in St. Peter’s Bay Stop #2 Spend a rejuvenating morning at Mysa Nordic Spa Stop #3 Head to the Eastern-most point of PEI to see the East Point Lighthouse Stop #4 Learn about the history of railroad on the Island at the Elmira Railway Museum Stop #5 In the friendly seaside town of Souris, walk the boardwalk and enjoy fresh seafood for dinner Stop #6 Catch a live music show at the Souris Show Hall Stop #7 Drive south and spend the night at Rodd Brudenell River Resort in Cardigan Stop #8 Get out on the water with Tranquility Cove Adventures Stop #9 Pick up a sandwich and fresh local berries at Nabuurs Gardens Stop #10 Step back in time for an afternoon at Roma National Historic Site Stop #11 Grab a coffee and shop around Montague Stop #12 Check out Bogside Brewing Taproom for dinner Stop #13 Drink in the sweeping views at Double Hill Cidery in Caledonia Stop #14 Wrap up your trip with a one-of-a-kind stay at Nellie’s Landing in Murray Harbour! Thanks for coming along on our road trip through Kings County, PEI! Got wanderlust? Hit the road and support Atlantic Canadian businesses!

item.title: Episode 8: New Country, New Taxes: Info for Newcomers and International Students
item.source: Taxology – The Official Canada Revenue Agency Podcast
item.content:encoded: If you are a newcomer or an international student (welcome!), this episode is for you. On top of learning the Canadian way of life, like managing the snow, ice skating, and how to pronounce poutine, you need to understand Canada’s tax system. Start here to find out about taxes in Canada and what benefit and credit payments you may be eligible for. Doing your taxes could help you. You may be able to claim education costs or get a tax refund, which is money in your pocket. Tax-free savings plans may also help you save for your future in Canada. Whether you’re a student starting your first year of post-secondary studies or a newcomer supporting your family this episode of Taxology will boost your tax literacy and give you the confidence to make informed tax decisions.

item.title: Elevating Canada’s Airline Competition
item.author: Competition Bureau Canada
item.content:encoded:
In 2024, the Bureau launched a market study to examine competition in Canada’s domestic airline industry and to make recommendations on how it could be improved.
The study – Cleared for take-off: Elevating airline competition—highlights the barriers that make it hard for new and smaller airlines to enter, grow and compete. It also examines how the lack of competition in the industry impacts Canadians, especially those in northern and remote communities where air transportation may be the only available option for essential services.
Read the report: https://can01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fcompetition-bureau.canada.ca%2Fen%2Fhow-we-foster-competition%2Feducation-and-outreach%2Fpublications%2Fcleared-take-elevating-airline-competition%3Futm_campaign%3Dcb-bc-social-media-25-26%26utm_medium%3Dsmo%26utm_source%3Dyt%26utm_content%3Dams-en-250619&data=05%7C02%7Cyves.chartrand%40cb-bc.gc.ca%7Cd2ce0a3bb5bd4c45baa608ddaf27d7b0%7Cb72ac62f06d54cd5824eee92319a4676%7C0%7C0%7C638859307842417914%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJFbXB0eU1hcGkiOnRydWUsIlYiOiIwLjAuMDAwMCIsIlAiOiJXaW4zMiIsIkFOIjoiTWFpbCIsIldUIjoyfQ%3D%3D%7C0%7C%7C%7C&sdata=R8ExA2DOS0vwp3JIzm6z5Hy5dbD5sXmZ9vo6xvgGEtA%3D&reserved=0
Available in French here: https://youtu.be/bzyABiPr8Jc

item.title: Innovative investments: Venture capital funding in agriculture and food
item.author: Agriculture and Agri-food Canada
item.content:encoded: Innovators take risks. And they need investors who are willing and informed to help them take the risks. Alison Sunstrum is a pioneering entrepreneur turned investor, now on a mission to fix the gaps she once faced—mentorship and access to capital—by investing in exceptional talent and bold ideas in agriculture. Graeme is part of the team at FCC Capital, which is a new effort from Farm Credit Canada to provide what he calls 'patient, and reliable capital' to agri-food and ag-tech companies across the country. Hear how these two and their teams are filling an important funding gap in Canada to help innovation in the ag sector.

item.title: S5 Ep. 02: Leveraging the Skills of Newcomers
item.content:encoded: In this episode of the , host Jeremy Strachan dives into the critical topic of leveraging the skills of newcomers to Canada and its impact on economic and social success. Joined by Tricia Williams from the Future Skills Centre, Sharon McLennon from the Newfoundland and Labrador Workforce Innovation Centre, and Shamira Madhany from World Education Services, the discussion explores how Future Skills Centre-funded initiatives have shed light on newcomer retention and workforce integration. The episode highlights barriers such as credential recognition, workplace bias, and lack of professional networks while emphasizing solutions like targeted upskilling, wraparound supports, and cultural competency training. With insights into workforce development across Canada, this episode underscores how effectively integrating skilled immigrants is key to addressing labor shortages and boosting economic resilience.Tricia Williams, PhD, Director of Research, Evaluation, and Knowledge Mobilization, Future Skills CentreSharon McLennon, Director, Newfoundland and Labrador Workforce Innovation CentreShamira Madhany, Managing Director and Deputy Executive Director, World Education Services

item.title: L'été à l'extérieur, prenez garde à la chaleur : Conseils pour travailler en toute sécurité dehors
item.content:encoded: À mesure que les journées s'allongent et que les températures grimpent, il est agréable de passer plus de temps dehors. Cependant, le travail à l'extérieur durant l'été comporte des risques particuliers. Dans cet épisode, nous examinons ces dangers et proposons des conseils pour que les employeurs et les travailleurs puissent y faire face.

item.title: Temps Up, Heads Up - Working Safely Outdoors
item.content:encoded: As days get longer and temperatures rise, it's great to be able to spend more time outside. But working outdoors in the summer comes with unique hazards. We take a look at what those hazards are, and how employers and workers can prepare.

item.title: Episode 7: Parenting Perks: About the Canada Child Benefit
item.source: Taxology – The Official Canada Revenue Agency Podcast
item.content:encoded: For all you parents out there! Maybe you have a newborn, adopted a child, or have a new parenting situation. If you have a new child in your life, it’s important to let the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) know since it can affect your taxes and benefits, like the Canada child benefit (CCB) On this episode of Taxology, a CRA expert explains the CCB, clarifies misconceptions and shares how you can apply. We can’t help you change diapers or build a crib, but we can help you get the benefits and credits you’re eligible for! So get that baby carrier on, and we will talk while you walk.

item.title: Porter Talk #5: The Women Who Stood With Porters
item.author: Discover Library and Archives Canada
item.content:encoded: Join us as we meet some of the strong and devoted women who stood with porters. Without their commitment and persistence, union gains would not have been possible in light of the men’s absence while working on the rails. (Episode 5) Transcript

item.title: H20: Home to Overseas Conference, 2025 – Halifax, Nova Scotia
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Halifax is buzzing with ocean innovation! The H2O Conference is back—Canada’s biggest ocean tech event and a global hub for marine innovation. Powered by ACOA and hosted by the Ocean Technology Council of Nova Scotia, it all wraps June 12 with Cove Demo Day! #MarineTech #OceanInnovation
Transcript So H2O is a platform that we use to showcase our ocean technology sector. It’s a way for our companies to come together and showcase their technologies and innovations and work with partners from around the world.
The conference has really grown and scaled over the last ten years.
It started out really as an industry showcase specifically for companies here in Nova Scotia.
But we've really grown it into an international conference with companies from all across Canada and around the world.
Having our international partners here is very important for the H2O conference and for our ocean technology sector as a whole.
We really have worked to turn H2O into an anchor event that's on the calendar of international partners and members of the ocean tech sector around the world.
So for us the ocean technology sector is predominantly driven by export.
So about 80% of our company's revenues come from export.
And with that we need to have partnerships; connections with our international markets.
And the H2O conference is a way to kind of bring those partners in and showcase what we do best here in Atlantic Canada.

item.title: Cruise Canada and New England Symposium, 2025 - Halifax, Nova Scotia
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Cruise tourism is making a big impact in Atlantic Canada. With support from ACOA, the Atlantic Canada Cruise Association is helping local communities thrive — one port at a time. Discover how Halifax and our region are welcoming the world while fueling inclusive economic growth across the East Coast.
Transcript Halifax, Nova Scotia is hosting the Cruise Canada and New England Symposium, where cruise leaders explore new ideas, technology and opportunities. Cruise ships help anchor Atlantic Canada's economy. With ACOA’s support, the Atlantic Canada Cruise Association champions our region as a top cruise destination, growing an industry that supports small businesses, boosts tourism, and enriches life in coastal communities. And in return we offer more than a stop. We share a story told through heritage, food, music and East Coast spirit. From our harbours to our hospitality, Atlantic Canada welcomes the world.

item.title: On Farm Climate Action in Action
item.author: Agriculture and Agri-food Canada
item.content:encoded: Farmers are taking action to protect the environment and strengthen the competitiveness of our agricultural sector. We speak with three producers who are leaders in reducing greenhouse gases, sequestering carbon, and building resilience against climate change. With support from the On-Farm Climate Action Fund (OFCAF), they’ve adopted beneficial management practices (BMPs) that make good business sense. Tune in to hear their insights and advice for fellow producers.

item.title: Episode 6: Explaining the Disability Tax Credit
item.source: Taxology – The Official Canada Revenue Agency Podcast
item.content:encoded: The disability tax credit (DTC) is a non-refundable credit that helps persons with disabilities who have a severe and prolonged physical or mental impairment affecting their daily lives. The credit can also help the family members who support the person with a disability to reduce the amount they may have to pay at tax time. In this episode, we chat with a CRA expert on the DTC, to help you understand the credit and the application process, and to clear up any misconceptions.

item.title: S5 Ep. 01 - What Quality of Work Means in a Changing Labour Market
item.content:encoded: What defines quality of work in today’s economy? In this episode, host Jeremy Strachan speaks with Laura McDonough from the Future Skills Centre and Dr. Olga Morawczynski from Heal-3 to explore how wages, job security, mental health, and workplace culture impact our experience at work. They discuss how research from the Future Skills Centre has shed insights on the evolving expectations of workers, the role of leadership in job satisfaction, and how benefits and training can shape long-term career well-being. As workplaces continue to change, and as Canada’s workforce challenges continue to evolve, understanding what job quality means is becoming more important than ever.

item.title: Losing Our Religion? It's Not That Simple
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: Is that Canada in the corner? In the spotlight? Are we losing our religion? The census found that 12.6 million people reported no religious affiliation in 2021, more than 1/3 of Canada's population. But is there more to the picture? With guests Simon-Pierre Lacasse, Senior Analyst at StatCan, and Sarah Wilkins-Laflamme, Associate Professor at the University of Waterloo, we're exploring what's driving this trend, whether "no religion" means "no spirituality," and how the story varies from spiritual British Columbia to the cultural Catholicism of Quebec to the freshly painted churches of Atlantic Canada.

item.title: Day of Mourning: Tracey Csordas' Story
item.content:encoded: Threads of Life Ambassador Tracey Csordas' life changed forever the day her brother died in a preventable workplace tragedy. Hear her powerful story.

item.title: Climate Change Impacts on Workplace Health and Safety with Dr. Sarah Henderson
item.content:encoded: Extreme weather events driven by climate change are happening across Canada with increasing frequency. Dr. Sarah Henderson joins us to discuss the potential impacts on workers and how workplaces can build more climate resiliency.

item.title: The Future of Work with Tyler Waye
item.content:encoded: The world around us is changing rapidly – and so is the workplace and what motivates us. Work and leadership strategist Tyler Waye joins us to discuss what employers and workers can do to build the thriving workplaces of the future.

item.title: Addressing Inequities in Personal Protective Equipment
item.content:encoded: When personal protective equipment is designed with diverse body types in mind, everyone in the workplace benefits. Dr. Amin Yazdani joins us to discuss how using breakthrough technology can shape the design of more inclusive PPE for workers in Canada.

item.title: Porter Talk: Episode 5 Trailer
item.author: Discover Library and Archives Canada
item.content:encoded: Join us as we meet some of the strong and devoted women who stood with porters. Without their commitment and persistence, union gains would not have been possible in light of the men’s absence while working on the rails. (Episode 5 trailer)TranscriptNarrator Biographies

item.title: What Does It Take to Exit Homelessness?
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: What is it that helps someone transition from homeless to housed? We’re looking at new analysis of data from the Canadian Housing Survey to explore exactly that. In conversation with Peter Tilley, the CEO of the Ottawa Mission, and Jeff Randle, Chief of the Housing Need Project section at Statistics Canada, we’re asking why homelessness (and homelessness data!) is more complex than you might think, what factors most often led to regaining housing, and why housing can be challenging to maintain even after it’s been regained.

item.title: Maritime Paper Products – Dartmouth, Nova Scotia
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Maritime Paper Products is a leading manufacturer of corrugated containers. An independent, family-owned company in Nova Scotia since 1931. With support from ACOA, the company is investing in modern, energy efficient equipment that will reduce waste and lower production expenses – reducing its carbon footprint and saving money at the same time.
Transcript Maritime Paper Products is a leading manufacturer of corrugated containers.
It’s an independent, family-owned company, established in Nova Scotia in 1931.
Corrugated cardboard is seen as a positive environmental option in the packaging sector.
Most cardboard is 100% recyclable, and bio-degradable within one year.
With assistance from ACOA, Maritime Paper has purchased advanced equipment to reduce waste and lower production costs.
By using less power, and diverting more waste, Maritime Paper expects to save money and help ensure success for generations to come.

item.title: Episode 5: How to be scam smart – Part 2
item.source: Taxology – The Official Canada Revenue Agency Podcast
item.content:encoded: “Hello, this is the Canada Revenue Agency…” – yes, it’s really us this time! However, there are bad actors who will impersonate employees of the CRA and other government departments for fraud and scam attempts. Some scams are easy to spot, and some are not! In this episode, we continue with information to protect yourself from these attempts. On the previous episode, we met with the Canadian Anti-Fraud Centre for tips on protecting yourself from fraud and scams. On this episode, we now meet with a CRA expert to discuss when and how the CRA may legitimately contact taxpayers, and how the CRA helps protect your information if you were scammed. We also meet with a member of the CRA’s marketing team, to talk about our efforts to inform Canadians about scams through the Be Scam Smart escape rooms you may have seen in malls across Canada in 2024.

item.title: Libra - Charlottetown, PEI
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Libra is a non-alcoholic craft beer company committed to helping its customers find their balance. Since 2020, Libra has secured distribution in 1,000 retail locations and restaurants across Canada including Sobeys, Loblaws, IGA, and Costco.
Transcript Libra is a non-alcoholic craft beer company committed to helping its customers find their balance. While working in the beverage industry, Mitch Cobb and Mike Hogan found themselves constantly sampling products and socializing. A non-alcoholic beer seemed like the answer. The brewers couldn't find a non-alcoholic craft beer that tasted like the real thing - so they made their own. After 2 years of research and development, Libra Non Alcoholic Craft Beer was launched in 2020. Libra is brewed just like a regular craft beer, with none of the alcohol and fewer calories. Leveraging the assets and relationships of Libra’s sister company Upstreet, the brew-master has created an agile product development pipeline. The non-alcoholic beer category is expected to grow at a rate of 7.8% over 10 years to $43.6B, according to Future Market Insights. Libra is recognized as a leading brand by international media and the craft beer community. The brewery has won several international beer awards, including "Canadian Non-Alcoholic Brewery of the Year" at the New York International Beer Competition. Since 2020, Libra has secured distribution in 1,000 retail locations and restaurants across Canada including Sobeys, Loblaws, IGA, and Costco. As retailers continue to see an increase in demand for non-alcoholic beer, Libra is focused on becoming the category leader in North America. The company is educating retailers and consumers on the benefits of incorporating non-alcoholic beverages to live a healthier lifestyle. In 2021, Canadian folk artist Serena Ryder was appointed Libra’s Chief Balance Ambassador. Together, they went on a mission to normalize socializing without alcohol. “Libra completely aligns with my core values ... it’s everything that I believe in, and I really love the beer.” - Serena Ryder Libra is proudly B Corp Certified, a global community of companies verified to meet high social and environmental standards. B Corps around the world are working together to redefine success in business and build a more inclusive and sustainable economy. ACOA is proud to support Libra as they create positive change and set the standard for the non-alcoholic beverage market.

item.title: The Health Impacts of Physically Demanding Work
item.content:encoded: Do physically active occupations make for healthier workers? Not necessarily. In this episode, Dr. Avi Biswas, scientist at the Institute for Work and Health, shares recommendations for safe, practical physical activity designed to meet the diverse needs of workers.

item.title: S4 Ep. 07: Labour Market Data & Disruption—Insights from FSC @ Cannexus25
item.content:encoded: In this special live mini episode of the Future Skills Podcast, recorded at Cannexus25 in Ottawa, host Jeremy Strachan explores how labour market information (LMI) is shaping career development, workforce planning, and skills training in a time of rapid change. Featuring insights from Jason Dennison (Fleming College), Tony Bonen (The Conference Board of Canada), and Tricia Williams (Future Skills Centre), the discussion unpacks how data-driven decision-making can help job seekers, educators, and policymakers navigate economic shifts, automation, and AI’s growing influence on the labour market.From understanding regional job trends to leveraging tools like OpportuNext for career transitions, this episode highlights the critical role of LMI in building a resilient workforce. What skills will be in demand? How can Canadians future-proof their careers? And, how do we make labour market data more accessible and actionable? We’ll hear three expert perspectives on the evolving skills ecosystem and what it means for the future of work.

item.title: Security Awareness (COR310)
item.author: TBS Canada
item.content:encoded:
To take the training: https://catalogue.csps-efpc.gc.ca/product?catalog=COR310&cm_locale=en General public access to the training: https://opn.csps-efpc.gc.ca/viewer/COR310-EN
This video was produced by the Communications team at the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat.
This video is also available in French: https://youtu.be/5ZfM9VskZMY

item.title: Cape Smokey – Ingonish, Nova Scotia
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Cape Smokey ski hill in Cape Breton is upgrading its power systems from the mid-point to the top of the hill to meet growing energy needs, make more snow, and phase out diesel for cleaner air and less noise.
Transcription Cape Smokey is making more snow and more tourism opportunities with more efficient energy. New, modern power systems at the ski hill will help meet energy and snowmaking needs while replacing diesel, for cleaner air and less noise. Investing in clean growth pays off: new markets, more jobs, accelerated growth, while minimizing environmental impacts. SMEs like Cape Smokey are leading the way by adopting new technologies and approaches to doing business.

item.title: Porter Talk #4: The Long Fight for Porters' Rights
item.author: Discover Library and Archives Canada
item.content:encoded: Join us as we delve into the inhumanity of portering, and the long fight for porters’ rights. (Episode 4) Transcript

item.title: S4 Ep. 06: Neurodivergent student experiences in post-secondary education
item.content:encoded: In this mini episode of the , Jeremy Strachan speaks with Dr. Jennifer Fane, Lead Research Associate at the Conference Board of Canada, about her recent study on neurodiversity in Canadian post-secondary education. The research, conducted in partnership with the Future Skills Centre, explores key findings from the report Creating Inclusive Campuses: Neuroinclusive Policies and Practices in Post-secondary Education.The discussion highlights the challenges neurodivergent students face, including their invisibility on campuses, complex accommodation processes, and persistent stigma. Dr. Fane calls for greater accessibility within equity, diversity, and inclusion (EDI) frameworks and offers practical recommendations, such as establishing neurodiversity hubs and providing campus-wide neurodiversity training.The episode also previews upcoming Future Skills Centre research on inclusive employment pathways for neurodivergent individuals.

item.title: Porter Talk: Episode 4 Trailer
item.author: Discover Library and Archives Canada

item.title: Mapping Happiness: How Where We Live Impacts Our Well-Being
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: It might not surprise you that your relationships with friends and family affect your well-being. Same with your health and your job. But what about the place where you live? Whether you live in the downtown core of a major city or a commuter town or a rural community, what impact does this have on your life satisfaction, loneliness and sense of belonging? StatCan’s Lauren Pinault joins us today at the mic to explore how the places we live affect our well-being.

item.title: Calculating crop rotation for potatoes
item.author: Agriculture and Agri-food Canada
item.content:encoded: Lori Robinson, a 6 generation farmer in PEI, is a data hound. As a result of her 50+ years of her and her family taking detailed notes and 20 + years of doing a four-year crop rotation system she laid the groundwork for a user-friendly calculator for crop rotations that has both economic benefits for producers and environmental benefits. Developed at the Living Labs initiative in PEI in conjunction with the PEI Potato Board, the calculator helps producers maximize profits while reducing their use of pesticides and improving soil health. And the story of the calculator has some interesting twists.

item.title: Episode 4: How to be scam smart – Part 1
item.source: Taxology – The Official Canada Revenue Agency Podcast
item.content:encoded: Did you know the Government of Canada has a department that helps police gather intelligence to protect Canadians from fraud and scams? Last year, Canadians lost $569M to fraud – and that’s just what was reported! In this episode, we get tips from the Canadian Anti-Fraud Centre (CAFC) to protect yourself from scammers. An expert from the CAFC joins us in this collaboration episode, to discuss the various fraud and scams she sees across the Government of Canada. We learn about the warning signs to look out for in fraudulent messages, the most common types of scams, and what to do if you or a family member may have been a victim to a scam.

item.title: Consommation de substances, stigmatisation et dépendance chez les hommes travaillant dans des métiers spécialisés
item.content:encoded: La stigmatisation à l'égard de la consommation de substances influe sur la façon dont nous parlons aux personnes, sur les politiques que nous élaborons et sur la prestation des soins. Dans cet épisode, la Dre Theresa Tam, administratrice en chef de la santé publique du Canada, et Anne Tennier, présidente et première dirigeante du CCHST, discutent des façons de réduire la stigmatisation et de soutenir les hommes dans les métiers spécialisés qui font face à des difficultés.

item.title: Substance Use, Stigma and Addiction Among Men in Trades
item.content:encoded: Stigma surrounding substance use affects how we talk to individuals, the policies we develop, and how we provide care. In this episode, Dr. Theresa Tam, Chief Public Health Officer of Canada, and Anne Tennier, President and CEO of CCOHS, discuss ways we can reduce stigma and support men in the trades who are struggling.

item.title: Porter Talk #3: All Aboard the Hotel on Wheels
item.author: Discover Library and Archives Canada
item.content:encoded: Join us as we explore the extraordinary demands placed on sleeping car porters by rail companies and passengers while working aboard the hotel on wheels. We will also hear about the various ways these men resisted and rose above anti-Black racism. (Episode 3)Transcript

item.title: Plant breeding: Long-game innovation in a fast-changing world
item.author: Agriculture and Agri-food Canada
item.content:encoded: How has plant breeding evolved over the past 20 years? Who are the players in Canada? What is the plant breeding continuum? And what is the proverbial sandbox in which Canadian plant breeders are working? Learn this and why it takes a special breed of innovator to become a plant-breeder.

item.title: Les principales questions sur la santé et la sécurité de 2024
item.content:encoded: Chaque année, le CCHST reçoit des questions sur la santé et la sécurité de tout le Canada. Nous discutons avec l'un de nos spécialistes techniques des questions les plus importantes et les plus fréquentes de l'année.

item.title: Top Health and Safety Questions of 2024
item.content:encoded: It's the year end roundup you've been waiting for: the top health and safety questions you asked us in 2024.

item.title: Porter Talk: Episode 3 Trailer
item.author: Discover Library and Archives Canada
item.content:encoded: Join us as we delve into the dire working conditions porters experienced as they traversed the country aboard the hotel on wheels. (Episode 3 trailer)TranscriptNarrator Biographies

item.title: S4 Ep. 05: Insights from Magnet Network Live
item.content:encoded: In this bonus episode of the , new host Jeremy Strachan dives into highlights from the Magnet Network Live event held in Toronto in October 2024, where leaders gathered to address Canada’s talent, training, and skills challenges. The episode features insights on AI, productivity, and Canada’s “12/21 problem,” where outdated learning models fall short in a 21st-century workforce. Key discussions focus on the need for risk-taking in business, the importance of social and emotional skills, and the critical role of trust in the workplace. Strachan also explores immigration’s role in Canada’s future, barriers faced by international students, and the impact of the Future Skills Centre’s efforts to foster an inclusive economy through innovative partnerships and initiatives across Canada. On October 23 and 24, 2024, Magnet Network hosted a two-day networking and knowledge-sharing event in Toronto’s distillery district. Featuring an array of speakers who are thought leaders, policymakers, and visionary idea accelerators in the skills ecosystem in Canada, Magnet Network Live (MNL) was a key forum for stakeholders to meet and hear insights on the pressing issues related to training, workforce development, and productivity in Canada. Conference Board of Canada was there in two capacities. Michael Burt, VP, was featured in a session alongside Candice Faktor, CEO of Disco, in a “fireside chat to explore why businesses are holding back on critical investments and how innovative learning models can shift this dynamic.” Jeremy Strachan, SRA, attended to record live audio as content for this episode. Content interviews and ambient and atmospheric textures of the event.Canada’s productivity puzzle remains unsolved, and a combination of skills waste, talent mismatch, and forecast labour shortages in key sectors like the skilled trades and the green economy are set to exacerbate our problems. MNL is one-of-a-kind event where attendees will hear from some of the best ideas on how to maximize our talent pool resources. Noel Baldwin, Executive Director of the Future Skills Centre Michael Burt, Vice President of the Conference Board of Canada Mark Patterson, Executive Director of Magnet Emily Madden, Senior Director of Magnet Ashok Kasilingam, CEO of M2M Tech Erin Rose, Senior Research Associate, Conference Board of Canada

item.title: Bear River First Nation, N.S.
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded: We’re grateful for projects that connect us to the earth and one another. Bear River First Nation, #Mikmaki is embracing those connections to drive economic development.

item.title: Town of Salisbury’s new amphitheatre - NB
item.author: ACOACanada
item.content:encoded:
Salisbury will soon host a variety of events, bringing people together in their new, vibrant community space. From concerts to community gatherings, the Salisbury amphitheatre is set to become a cornerstone of local entertainment and engagement. Plus, with the addition of a new trail system for walking and biking, there's even more to explore and enjoy. #gc
Transcript: So, we've had this dream for many, many years. But of course, it takes funding to do these types of things. And as a small community, we don't always have the resources to make these things happen. So obviously when we approached ACOA with the idea and the relevance as well as the opportunities and the benefits for our community ACOA came forward obviously with funding. The importance of the amphitheater as well as the connecting trail to our residents is something that they've been asking for for many, many years. As Canada's most active community in 2023, we show that having a very connected community is important where people can walk trails and do recreational activities. The amphitheater was one of those where we could bring people together in our community, connecting place where we can grow as one. And we're just so thrilled to have this happening in our community.

item.title: Can Your Business Outsmart a Hacker?
item.author: Statistics Canada
item.content:encoded: Over two thirds (70%) of Canadians experienced a cyber security incident in 2022. The strategies used by bad actors are getting more and more complex. Many of us are inundated with what feels like never-ending phishing emails, scam text messages and fraudulent phone calls. It’s rare to talk to someone who hasn’t experienced some form of a cyber attack. The situation is no different for Canadian businesses. Identity theft, scams, fraud, and ransomware are only some of the ways cyber attackers are targeting businesses today. One cyber security breach can cost a business thousands of dollars and valuable time resources to neutralize. We wanted to know: Is cyber crime on the rise in Canada? What is the relatively new phenomenon of cyber risk insurance? And in what way are consumers affected when a business experiences a security breach? The Canadian Survey of Cyber Security and Cyber Crime has published new data and, in this episode, we sat down with Howard Bilodeau, an economist at Statistics Canada to answer our questions about how cyber security is changing for businesses and what it means for the rest of us.

item.title: Prevent Slips, Trips and Falls with Good Workplace Housekeeping
item.content:encoded: Good workplace housekeeping might seem like a simple concept, but it doesn't always get the respect it deserves. Learn how effective housekeeping can reduce the risk of slips, trips and falls, one of the most common lost-time injuries.

item.title: Prévenir les glissades, trébuchements et chutes grâce à une bonne tenue des locaux de travail
item.content:encoded: La bonne tenue des locaux de travail peut sembler un concept simple, mais elle n'est pas toujours reconnue à sa juste valeur. Découvrez comment une tenue efficace des locaux peut réduire le risque de glissades, de trébuchements et de chutes, qui sont à l'origine de blessures entraînant une absence au travail parmi les plus courantes.

item.title: GC Digital Talent Platform Instructional Video
item.author: TBS Canada
item.content:encoded:
The GC Digital Talent platform instructional video helps individuals create a profile and navigate through the process to apply for digital talent opportunities in the Government of Canada.
This video is also available in French: https://youtu.be/SD794Uv8K6A
